The fader þe sone, and þe suster þe broþer;
Men and wymmen her childern ete,
And eche ete oþer by þe strette.
A ryche lady of þat countre
Of large londes and of fe,
Marye sche hiȝte, sykerliche,
A crystenwoman priueliche,
Sche had a queyntaunce in Jerusa∣lom,
And þerfor sche þider come.
A good lady, þat sche had yknowe,
Wiþ hir sche þouȝt to dwelle a þrowe.
Dame Claryce was hir name,
A woman of wel holy fame.
Thei lyued þere togeder longe,
That þis wo byfylle so stronge.
Oþer werke cowde þei none worche,
But dwelle moche in holy chirche
And lye in her afflixcions,
In penaunce and in orysons.
So hit byfylle, what more, what lesse,
That þei were boþ in gret dy∣stresse.
For defaute of mete and drynke
That dye þei muste for any þinke.
Hem was no lyflode ylost,
But al forrobbed and al forrefte.
Marye had a douȝtter dere,
That for hunger dyed þere;
For wham sche made moche sorowe
Boþ an euen and a morowe.
And þei hemself so gret hunger had,
That Dame Claryce to Marye bad:
'Ete we nowe þis child anoon
For þe hunger, þat vs is on.'
'Nay, quod Marye, þat wol I noȝt;
Dye I wolde, or hit come in my þouȝt.
Oure lord god, þat is so hende,
Of his grace may vs sende;
Be we noȝt for þis to sory,
Hit may vs stonde in purgatorye.'
So schul al, þat wel byleue,
That no wo ne schal him greue.
In þis talkyng, ryȝt as þei satte,
Jesus crist hem noȝt forȝate.
An aungel come fro heuene shene,
As god him sent hem bytwene,
And seid to hem: 'Letteþ ȝoure stryffe;
Al þat ȝe mowe, lengþeþ ȝoure lyffe;
Marye, loke nowe, þat þou do so,
As charyte seid þe raþer to.
God wol, þat ȝe do so, raþer þan ȝe dye,
To fulfylle þe prophecye,
That spekeþ of þis by waye and strete,
That wymmen schal her childern ete.
Grocheþ noȝt to fulfylle
Al, þat is goddes wylle;
Thouȝ ȝe dye in his nede,
Heuene-blysse schal be ȝoure mede.'
Whan þe aungel had seid his sawe,
Aȝen to heuene he gan to drawe.
Thei putte þe childe on a spytte
Aȝens þe fyer, to roste hit,
And dude, as þe aungel hem bad:
Thei ete þerof and made hem glad.
And as Pylate satte in his towre,
Of roste he had a gret sauoure,
And where hit was, anoon hit was outsouȝt;
He bad, to him hit schulde be brouȝt.
Thei went and founde, where hit was,
And come and tolde him al þat cas.
Than was Pylate noþing fawe,
Whan þei had tolde þis sawe.
And þo þe Jewes þider rune
Vppon his erande þei bygune.
The wymmen hungred and were ful wo,
That þei her lyflode bare hem fro.
For þis siȝt þei were in drede,
That þei dude þat luþer dede.
Pylate had hunger none,
Thouȝ her vitaylles were al agon;
Ne none of þe oþer gret,
Thouȝ þe pore dyde for defaute of mete.
For þei had þe noble stones
Of gret vertye for þe nones,
And þat made hem laste so longe,
Tyl al þe peple hem amonge
No lenger suffer ne wolde,
Than god þat had þe termes tolde.
Pylate þo in þe towne let crye
And forbad þe felonye,
That no man schuld no more ette
In þat wyse her bygete.
But gold and syluer ete he bad
To al þilke, þat any had.
Than þei ete her tresoure al,
Boþ hey and corn wiþal.
And ȝit for al þat dyed manyone,
In euery street wel gret won;
For hit was no kyndely fode
In no stede hit hem stoode,
But hem al to be kylde,
Whan þe towne was ȝelde.
For to haue out þe tresoure
Men pyned hem wel þe bytteroure.
Eche oþer day þei dude ete,
For deynte þei helde hit swete.
The wyff þe housbonde and þe hous∣bonde þe wyff,
Eche bynome oþers lyff,
Som wiþ teeþ oþer to gnawe,
Som wiþ handes oþer to drawe.
So þicke þei dyde by street and way
For stynke of dede, þat adowne lay;
For þe comyne raunsoun
Thei buryed þe bodyes of þe towne,
And whan hem fayled tresoure,
Than dude þei burye hem no more,
But leyde hem togeder alle,
Thilke þat for hunger þere gune falle.
Than stancke þe towne, hit was so fylde
Of deed bodyes, þat lay vnhylde,
That fader and moder, suster and broþer
Dyde, þat no man myȝt burye oþer.
Siþþe whan þe towne was ytake,
Tytus mochel moone gan make;
For þe peple so þicke laye
On hepes, dyde by euery waye.
Downe he fel uppon boþ knee.
'Lord, he seide, for me fader and me,
For þoruȝ vs þei lye noȝt so deed,
But for her owne feble rede.
Had þei raþer yturned to vs,
Than had þei noȝt leye þus.'
Dyches þei let make and belde
And þerin þe bodyes þei helde.
Pylate anoon his counseille gan take,
For drede þo he gan to quake.
Thei seid to him: 'We redeþ þe,
Let ȝelde vp anoon þe cytee;
Thus, þinkeþ vs al, hit is þe best,
Herein schul we haue no rest.'
'Nay, quod Pylate, þis is my rede:
I wote, þer is no wey but deede;
Ȝit we wol a while abyde
For to se, what wol betyde.
Thise lordes mowe dye, þat beþ without,
Here amydde al þe rowte;
Than dar we care litel wiþ alle,
On wheþer syde so hit falle.
Oþer we schul do, as I schal seye
To seche vs helpe anoþer weye:
Caste we, what we wol hem ȝeue
Here to dwelle and to leue.'
To þis þei graunted euerychon
And cast, howe þei wold don.
The while, þat þei cast hit so,
The Emperoure seid to Jacob: 'Go
And speke to som of þat cytee
And wyte, at what poyntement þei be,
And loke, wheþer þei wolle ȝelde þe towne
Forto come out of pryson.
For þei haueþ noȝt al her wylle,
I trowe, for hunger þat som spylle.
Go now þider for wete I wolde,
Whereto we schulle vs holde.
They dyed adowne in þe street
For hunger and no meet.
Sey, þei come and ȝelde hem vs to
For at þe last þei schul do so.'
Tho Jacob went to þe walle,
A Jewe he sawe and he gan him calle.
'Clepe me þere, he seid, Josephus,
Bydde him come and speke wiþ vs.'
He wente and brouȝt him also swyþe;
Jacob of him was ful blyþe
And he of him was also.
Than quod Josephus: 'Howe come þou vs fro?'
He tolde him þo, howe hit was;
And he seid þo: 'Deo gracias.'
'What, quod Jacob, art þou cristen?'
'Ȝee, felawe, he seid, wolt þou lys∣tenne:
I am a preuy cristenman,
And my feiþ ful wel I can:
To loue Crist ful wel I owe.
And þat I am to þe yknowe:
This oþer day, þo we out nome,
Whan þat ȝe vs ouercome,
I was ywonded þere ful sore,"
That I was nyȝe deed þerfore;
And þoruȝ þe myracle of Jesu
Nowe I am ryȝt hole ynowe.
My fader and moder I haue tolde
To turne hem, and þei ne wolde;
And þat I may noȝt hem bryngge þerto,
Therfor, Jacob, me is ful wo.'
'Ȝee, quod Jacob, holde þe stylle
And þou schalt haue al þi wylle;
And I schal be for þe, ȝif I can,
To my lord Waspasian;
And al þilke, þat cristen be,
Whan þis is do, þou schalt yse.
Sey me nowe, howe fare ȝe þer within
And whan schul we þe towne ywynne?'
'Mafey, he seid, I wol þe sey,
Ful þicke oure folke gynneþ to dye,
And for þe styncke, þat comeþ hem fro,
In þe cytee dyeþ manyone þe mo.
And þerfor we haueþ let make
Amydde þe towne a gret lake;
Al þilke, þat deed doþ falle,
In þat lake we casteþ hem alle.'
'Mafey, quod Jacob, and so do we;
And he seid: hit was firste þoruȝ me.
Me þinkeþ, þei doþ gret folye
To holde aȝens god and oure par∣tye;
And ȝit I hope at þe laste
To wynne þis towne þoruȝ my caste,
As Pylate seid amydde þe towne.
And þo he dude me in prison,
That I and Veronye with good spede
That we procured al þis nede.
Forsoþe, he gabbed þerof ryȝt noȝt,
I wene, þerto hit wol be brouȝt;
Forsoþe, my broþer Josephus,
I wysshed to god, hit myȝt be þus.
And dame Veronye, þe good woman,
Byfore þe styward Velesian
I made þat dame Veronye ȝede
For to boten þe Emperoures nede.
Therfor I am with him pryue,
So, I hope, ȝit þou schalt be.
So helpe me Crist, nowe I am glad,
That hit schal falle, as I bad.
The Emperoure was wonder-syke
And wende to haue ydyed eke;
And god haþ heled him þoruȝ his grace,
And also ymade him to seke þis place.
He þinkeþ al þe Jewes shende,
Er þat he hennys wol wende.
He wyl neuer let þis towne,
Tyl al togeder be bete adowne.
Thou myȝt yse, hit is goddes wylle
This veniaunce to fulfylle.
By many tokens men may yse
And þou wolt beþinke þe:
Al þilke, þat beþ þerin,
Beþ encombred in gret synne,
But hit be any preuy crystenman
Late yturned to god þan.
And for þei wol no mercy craue,
I telle þe, þei schul none haue
Neiþer of god, ne of man,
Neiþer of my lord Waspasian;
For he and his sone Tytus, boþ,
Wiþ al þe Jewes þei beþ so wroþ;
That oþe þei made, þei nyl noȝt breke
Ne leue þe sege, tyl þei be awreke.
Therfor I prey þe, sey me sone,
What þei þinkeþ þerin to done;
Wheþer þei wol þe towne holde,
Oþer haue ydo and vp hit ȝolde.'
Josephus answerde him ful stylle:
'Jacob, hit was noȝt last her wylle,
That þei wold also do.
Whan þat I come to þe hem fro,
I wote, forsoþ I telle hit þe,
Hit dureþ noȝt long, as þinkeþ me.
Me were wel leuer, we were wiþout,
For we lyueþ here in doute.
I wene, þei casteþ to make agree,
Ȝif þei mowe, wiþ any fee.
Prey for vs and be us for,
That no cristenman be forlor.
For had my lord Waspasian
Ymade himself a cristenman
And his sone wiþ al his ost,
Er he come hyder, wel þou wost.
For him hit had be sykernys,
Than had we ȝelde vs boþ more and lesse.
Ȝit is vs leuere to dye here in pyne,
Than ȝelde vs to a Saraȝyne;
But we holde vs worþi more,
Tyl nede dryue vs to suffre sore.
Fare wel, Jacob, my leue broþer,
Ȝe schul sone wyte anoþer.'
'Nowe god of heuene be wiþ þe
And al, þat þerein cristen be.'
The Emperoure anoon he come to;
Worde for worde he tolde him þo.
Than answerde þe Emperoure:
'Sone I hope scape þis erroure.
By þise wordes nowe I se,
On haste þei schulle ȝelde be.
Jacob, wake we al, þat we may.
Hit nyȝeþ fast þe terme-day.'
Josephus come þe Jewes to.
'Lordyngges, he seid, what wol ȝe do?
Waspasian ne Tytus, his sone,
For wreche leue þei ne kone.
Tyl þei haue wreke her tene;
And þat wol newlyche here bysene.
So moche I wote, Syr Pylate,
As I haue asspyed here nowe late,
I can noȝt se no waye but one,
That we be noȝt here deed euer∣ychon:
Loke, what al oure folke wol sey,
And doþ nowe ryȝt, as I ȝou prey.
For certes, Syr, þe comynte
Makeþ moone more þan we.'
A crye was made, þat þe folke come al,
Boþ þe gret and þe smal.
Than Pylate seid: 'What rede ȝe nowe?
We doþ vs al vppon ȝou.'
The peple byfore him made a crye
Ful rewþeful and ful gryslye
And seid: 'Feyrer hit were to dye,
Than in þis myschieff longe to lye.'
And som of hem seid amonge:
'We lyeþ herein ysperryd to longe,
We dyeþ here in gret dystresse.
And þat is for oure wyckednesse,
For we dude Messias to dye;
Hit is his wylle, þat we hit abye,
And þat sheweþ þe Romaynes ful wel,
For to him we were unlele.
Som tyme hit was, we fyndeþ hit so,
That þe Romaynes þus schul do,
Whan we and oure kynde ran
Forto destroye þe good man.
By þis we mowe knowe and se,
The tyme is come, þat hit schal so be.
Hit semeþ, Messias may fulfylle
Of al þing to do his wylle;
For lengger with no maner gynne
Ne mowe we last for oure synne.
He sheweþ wel, þat he is god al∣myȝt;
We dude as foles wiþ him to fyȝt,
We byddeþ his mercy al to late,
And þou also, Syr Pylate.
Therfor let vs al out gon,
To ende oure sorowe ryȝt anoon.'
'And ȝit, seid som hem amonge,
Wel better is shortte sorowe þan longe:
To sle eche oþer fayrer hit ys,
Than ȝelde vs vp and fare amys.'
A eleuen þousand þere lost her lyff,
Eche slowe oþer with his knyff;
And for þe stynche, þat of hem come,
Manyone his deþ þere þei nome.
And þan þei cryed at one crye
To Jesu crist, þat sytteþ an hiȝe:
'Aȝens þe lord we haue mysdon,
That suche a wreche comeþ vs on.
Nowe mowe we sey, as he dude,
Whan he toward þe crosse ȝede;
He bad vs wype noȝt for him,
But for vs self and for oure kynne.
We mowe warye al oure kynde
For þe sorowe, þat we fynde;
Wiþout ende mote þei care,
That makeþ vs þus yuel to fare.
Nowe is come, þat he vs behiȝt:
Aȝens oure wrong he doþ vs ryȝt.
Forþi, Pylate, ȝeue up þe towne
And let vs go out of presoun;
Oþer we schulle þe smertlyche take
And al þe grettest eke forsake
And ȝelde oureself þis cytee,
Howe so euer hit of vs be.
Thereof besy þe, Syr Pylate,
Oþer þou schalt be siþþe ware al to late;
For we mowe no lenger lyue,
Hye, þat þe towne were vp yȝeue.'
Whan Pylate sawe þis and Josephus,
Barabas and Archilaus,
Thei and þe peple went al
And to þe Emperoure þei gan calle:
'The tyme is come, as we þe telle,
That we ne mowe no lenger dwelle;
For we haue do al, þat we may.
Of seuene ȝeer þis is þe last day;
Therfor, Syr, we þe preye,
Wheþer schulle we lyue or dye or wende aweye.'
Tho þe Emperoure þis wordes herde,
Wiþ mochel ioye forþ he ferde.
Also swyþe he gan downe falle
On his knees byfore hem alle
And seid: 'Welcome be goddes sonde,
For he is lord of al londe.
Nowe I se, he wol fulfylle,
That I schal haue al my wylle.'
He arose and spake to hem al:
'Hereþ nowe, what schal byfalle;
That ȝe schulle hure yspeke and se:
Ȝe schulle no mercy fynde in me!
For ȝe slowe in þis stedde
Jesu crist in his manheed
Wiþout any gylte, al for eye;
Nadde ȝe be, I had him seye.
Ȝe haue fayled of his grace,
So schulle ȝe of myn in þis place!
Al my wylle I haue ȝou tolde,
Whereto ȝe schulle now ȝou al holde.'
Than seid þe kyng Archilaus:
'Syr Emperoure, schal hit nowe go þus?'
He gan to rente a gappe wyde
Adowne anoon be his syde;
Anoon his swerde out he drowe
And þerwiþ himself he slowe;
He fel adowne tofore hem alle
Into þe dyche ouer þe walle.
'Forsoþe, þo seid þe Emperoure,
Archilaus was a traytoure;
Therfor in suche a deþ he sterued,
As he had ryȝt deserued.
Go, burye him uppon al þing
Wiþ honoure, for he was a kyng.'
Pylate and al þei wente adowne
To þe ȝate of þe towne,
He went out þo, I vnderstonde,
Wiþ þe keyes in his honde;
The ȝate was openyd with sorowe most.
And Tytus was redy wiþ his ost,
When þe towne schulde be ȝelde and take.
In þe pres gan outshake
Josephus wiþ many a man
Into þe cytee of Jenopoȝam,
For to ascape al þe wo,
That þe Jewes schuld to.
The Emperoure wyst hit al in hast
And sone after he was bycast
Wiþ men of armes, wiþ many a gynne,
Nyȝt and day þe towne to kepyn.
And Josephus strongly þere wiþ∣stode,
Er þat he wold shedde his bloode
To þe Emperoure, Syr Waspasian,
For he was no cristenman.
But I am syker, at þe last
The Emperoure þouȝt on him so fast,
That þe sege he let be.
And wiþ a. x. felawes he gan fle
Vnder þe erþe into a caue,
Hem to socoure and to saue.
Whan her vytailles were al gon,
His felawes seid euerychon:
'Syr, þus mowe we noȝt here lye;
But ȝif we wol abyde and dye,
Eche of vs schal oþer ete
At þe last for nede of mete.'
Than Josephus answerde as a man
Queyntelyche, as nede was þan:
'Nay, hit wylle noȝt wel be so.
Cast we lotte bytwene two and two,
Whiche of vs schal oþer ete
And whiche we schulle alyue lete.
Holde ȝe al nowe to þis?'
'Ȝee, þe[i] seid, forsoþe ywys!'
Thus eche of hem to nam,
Tyl þat hit to Josephus cam,
That þe lotte fyl him vppon;
And dye he muste ryȝt anoon.
But god wolde noȝt, þat he schuld dye þan,
For his witte holpe many a man.
Hys felawe gan þo his swerde to drawe
And Josephus þerwiþ he wold haue slawe.
Josephus þo—þat sotyl was—
Sawe, þat he was nyȝe þat cas,
He lepe on him, ryȝt as he cam,
And his swerde he him bynam.
The same dome he him gaue,
That he schuld himself haue.
And he hem lefte þere aloon
And so he come out by him one
Wiþ his swerde in his honde
And to þe Emperoure þo he wonde.
The Emperoure to him Josephus drowe
And seid: 'Felawe, who art þou?'
'Syr, he seid, I hiȝt Josephus,
That wrote þe story amonge vs,
Al þat euer in wrytte I cowde fynde
Amonge þe Jewes and al her kynde.'
The Emperoure seid to him: 'þou art asspye,
Thou schalt be bonde, tyl þou dye.
For me þinkeþ, þou seyst amys;
Ȝif þou haddest be so wyse,
Whi haddyst þou noȝt ywarned hem to saue
Fro þe harmes, þat þei schul haue?'
'Syr, seid Josephus him to,
Vppon hem, þat hit hurde, ȝit I hit do,
That I warned hem of þis cas
Fele ȝeres, or hit was;
And of her bokes I take wytnesse,
That I haue wrytte, as I gesse.'
The bokes of þe lawe were brouȝt echon,
And þo him lyued manyone,
And al þei wytnessed in þat stedde,
That Josephus hit wrote and to hem so seid.
Than spake Jacob for him þore:
'Al, þat he haþ ydo, I wol be fore.'
Tho seid Syr Waspasian:
'Josephus, art þou a crystenman?'
'Ȝee, Syr, he seid, sykerly,
But I haue ybore hit pryuely.'
Ryȝt anoon he was vnbounde
And þanked god þat ylke stounde.
'Syr, he seid, ȝif þou wolt loke,
Ȝit þou schalt fynde in þis boke,
That I seid: þin was þe honoure,
Of Rome to be Emperoure,
Fourty dayes, or hit fylle,
And howe Syr Tytus forȝede his hele.
And þoruȝ þe counselle ȝit of me
I hope, hole þat he schal be.'
Than was þe Emperoure ful glad
And seid þo: 'I haue, þat I bad.'
Than seid: 'Master Josephus,
I nolde forgo my sone Tytus,
And þou myȝt his lyffe saue;
No þing but þin al þat I haue.
Mochel honoure þe schal be ȝeue
And þou may helpe him to lyue.'
'Syr, he seid, haue no drede,
I hope ful wel, we schul spede.'
He wente þo to Tytus swyþe,
Of his companye he was blyþe.
When Tytus hurde his faders sawe,
To Josephus þan he gan him drawe.
He loued siþþe Josephus most,
Saue his fader, of al þe ost.
On a day he seid to Josephus:
'Whan schal hit be do, þat þou hiȝttest vs?'
'Syr, he seid, to morowe-day
Hit schal be do, ȝif I may.
Come to morowe and ete with vs þan,
And I schal be redy, ȝif þat I can.
One forwarde I bydde, þat þou ne wreþe þe
Wiþ þat man, þat I bryngge with me.'
'I schal come by þis couenaunt,
Parfay, quod Tytus, and I graunt.'
Josephus in his þouȝt gan cast
And byþouȝt him at the last:
Wiþ a ioye come his yuel, parfay,
And wiþ a sorowe hit most away.
Anoon he dude to spye þan,
Ȝif þere were euer any man,
That Tytus had hated stronge
And þe wreþþe ylasted longe.
Tho him was tolde of sucheone,
He let him come forþ anoon;
And ryȝt anoon he let calle
The styward of þe kyngges halle.
Tho seid Josephus: 'Good felawe,
Wolt þou do after my sawe,
Loke, þat þou assent to me nowe
For Tytus loue and for his prowe.'
'Syr, he seid, sykerlyche,
I grauntte to do hit bleþelyche.'
'Wel, seid Josephus, also sone
As mete-tyme is at noon,
Do me feche a lytel borde
Ryȝt byfore Tytus, my lord;
And þerat schal þis man be set.
And loke, þat him be mete yfet,
Gret plente, and also drynke,
As schal come byfore a kyng.
And ȝif I rehete him, do þou so.'
'Syr, quod þe styward, hit schal be do.'
Al þis was ydo worde for worde.
Tho þe man satte at þe kyngges borde,
Tytus was agreued in his þouȝt,
How þis man was þider y-brouȝt.
Thus he satte agreued longe,
That mete ne drynke wold he none fonge.
For tene he chaunged al his mode,
That suche an heet come in his blode,
That his yuel him forsoke
And neuer after him ne toke.
Josephus þan byhelde þis man
And comforte him, þo he bygan;
And þe styward dude also
Wiþ fayre semblante and speche þerto.

DIV1.P: Auf eine durchgehende Säuberung des Textes, wozu viel Anlass vorhanden wäre, sowie auf eine sprachliche und stilistische Untersuchung des Denkmals verzichte ich, da die hier abge∣druckte Hs. nicht die einzige ist, die wir besitzen.

'Vindicta Salvatoris' ist nämlich, wie Walter Suchier gesehen hat, eine Teilfassung der me. Dichtung 'Vengeaunce of goddes deth' oder 'Battle of Jerusalem', ohne die ersten 812 Verse und mit vielen abweichenden Lesarten. Von der 'Vengeaunce' waren bisher sechs Hss. bekannt; heizu kommt jetzt die oben gedruckte als siebente. Alle weitere Forschung wird warten müssen, bis F. Bergau wenigstens von den vier Hss., die ihm zugänglich sind, seine lange geplante Ausgabe veröffentlicht; vgl. inzwischen seine Diss. (Untersuchungen über Quelle und Verfasser des me. Reim∣gedichts 'The vengeaunce of goddes deth', Königsberg 1901) und dazu die Anzeige von Walter Suchier, Archiv CXI 285-298.
